  - coditect-license-manager

messages.content:
Excellent approach. Let's design this properly since you'll live with it
  long-term. Here's a comprehensive analysis:

  Design Principles for Professional Naming

  Must achieve:
  1. Immediate clarity - Anyone can understand the repo's purpose at a
  glance
  2. Alphabetical sorting - Groups related repos in GitHub and file
  explorers
  3. Scalability - Works with 30 repos or 300 repos
  4. Onboarding - New team members/customers understand the structure
  instantly
  5. Professional - Looks like a mature enterprise product

  ---
  Three Strong Options

  Option A: Category Prefixes (Recommended)

  Short, clear prefixes that group related repos:

  coditect-core-*      # Foundation layer
  coditect-cloud-*     # Cloud platform services
  coditect-dev-*       # Developer tools
  coditect-market-*    # Marketplace & features
  coditect-docs-*      # Documentation & content
  coditect-ops-*       # Operations & deployment
  coditect-gtm-*       # Go-to-market & business
  coditect-labs-*      # Research & experiments

  Example mapping:
  BEFORE                              AFTER
  ------                              -----
  coditect-cloud-backend          →   coditect-cloud-backend (stays)
  coditect-cloud-frontend         →   coditect-cloud-frontend (stays)
  coditect-framework              →   coditect-core-framework
  coditect-infrastructure         →   coditect-core-infrastructure
  coditect-project-dot-claude     →   coditect-core-dotclaude
  coditect (installer)            →   coditect-core-distribution
  coditect-cli                    →   coditect-dev-cli
  coditect-automation             →   coditect-dev-automation
  coditect-analytics              →   coditect-dev-analytics
  coditect-agent-marketplace      →   coditect-market-agents
  coditect-docs                   →   coditect-docs-main
  coditect-legal                  →   coditect-docs-legal
  coditect-blog-application       →   coditect-docs-blog
  coditect-competition            →   coditect-gtm-competition
  communications                  →   coditect-gtm-communications
  az1.ai-CODITECT.AI-GTM         →   coditect-gtm-strategy

  Pros:
  - Clear grouping in any sorted list
  - Intuitive category names
  - Easy rules for new repos ("Is this cloud? dev? docs?")
  - Scales well (just add repos to categories)

  Cons:
  - Slightly longer names
  - Some repos might fit multiple categories

  ---
  Option B: Flat with Clear Names

  No prefixes, just clear descriptive names:

  coditect-backend
  coditect-frontend
  coditect-cli
  coditect-framework
  coditect-marketplace
  coditect-docs
  coditect-analytics
  coditect-distribution

  Pros:
  - Shortest names
  - Simple
  - Works like Stripe, Vercel

  Cons:
  - Doesn't group in alphabetical lists
  - Harder to navigate at scale (50+ repos)
  - Less obvious hierarchy

  ---
  Option C: Numbered Tiers

  Explicit hierarchy with numbers:

  coditect-1-core-*       # Foundation
  coditect-2-platform-*   # Cloud services
  coditect-3-features-*   # Product features
  coditect-4-tools-*      # Developer tools
  coditect-5-docs-*       # Documentation
  coditect-9-labs-*       # Research

  Pros:
  - Absolute sorting control
  - Very explicit hierarchy
  - Visual indication of importance

  Cons:
  - Looks more technical/internal
  - Numbers feel arbitrary
  - Less intuitive

  ---
  My Recommendation: Option A (Category Prefixes)

  Here's why:

  1. GitHub navigation - When you have 30+ repos, seeing them grouped by
  coditect-cloud-*, coditect-dev-*, coditect-docs-* is immediately useful
  2. Professional appearance - Companies like Google (google-cloud-*), AWS
  (aws-*-sdk), Microsoft (microsoft-*) use similar patterns
  3. Scalable governance - Easy to enforce "all cloud repos must be
  coditect-cloud-*"
  4. Onboarding - New developers instantly know where to look: "I need the
  CLI → coditect-dev-cli"
  5. Flexible - Categories can hold 1 repo or 20 repos

  Would you like me to:
  1. Create the full rename mapping for all 29 repos using Category
  Prefixes?
  2. Explore a different approach?
  3. Refine the category names?

> is this renaming going to cause a lot of code refactoring?

  Design Principles for Professional Naming

  Must achieve:
  1. Immediate clar...

messages.content:
Great practical question. Let me assess the actual impact:

  What Renaming Affects

  Low/No Impact (No Code Changes)

  - Internal code - Imports use relative paths, not repo names
  - Submodule references - Update .gitmodules, run git submodule sync
  - Local development - Just re-clone or update remotes

  Medium Impact (Config/Doc Updates)

  - .gitmodules - Update all URLs (automated, one file)
  - READMEs - GitHub links need updating
  - CI/CD workflows - Repo name references in GitHub Actions
  - CLAUDE.md files - Any hardcoded repo URLs

  Higher Impact (Needs Careful Handling)

  - install.sh / update.sh - Uses
  raw.githubusercontent.com/halcasteel/coditect/...
  - Published packages - If any repos are npm/PyPI packages
  - External documentation - Customer-facing links

  Good News

  GitHub redirects help: When you rename a repo, GitHub automatically
  redirects the old URL to the new one. This means:
  - Existing clones still work
  - Old links don't immediately break
  - You have time to update references

  Estimated Effort

  | Task                   | Time    | Automation         |
  |------------------------|---------|--------------------|
  | Rename repos on GitHub | 30 min  | Manual (GitHub UI) |
  | Update .gitmodules     | 10 min  | Script             |
  | Update install.sh URLs | 15 min  | Manual             |
  | Update READMEs/docs    | 1-2 hrs | Search & replace   |
  | Update CI workflows    | 30 min  | Grep & edit        |

  Total: ~3-4 hours of config/doc updates, not code refactoring.

  The Real Question

  Do you want to:
  1. Rename now - Clean slate, 3-4 hours of updates, done forever
  2. Rename incrementally - Do a few at a time as you touch them
  3. Keep names, reorganize structure - Use GitHub topics/folders instead

  What's your preference?

> we have over a hundred repositories between AZ1.AI and CODITECT

messages.content:
With 100+ repos across multiple orgs, we need to think bigger than just
  naming. Let me update the approach:
messages.content_preview:
With 100+ repos across multiple orgs, we need to think bigger than just
  naming. Let me update the approach:

messages.content:
Enterprise-Scale Repository Strategy

  With 100+ repos, renaming alone won't solve the problem. Here's a
  strategic approach:

  Step 1: Consolidate Organizations First

  Current state: Repos scattered across coditect-ai, halcasteel, az1-ai,
  etc.

  Target state: Single source of truth

  | Option             | Pros                                       | Cons
                      |
  |--------------------|--------------------------------------------|-------
  --------------------|
  | All in coditect-ai | Product-focused, clean for customers       | Need
  to transfer repos    |
  | All in az1-ai      | Company umbrella, room for future products | Less
  product clarity      |
  | Keep split         | No migration work                          |
  Confusing, unprofessional |

  Recommendation: coditect-ai for all product repos (since CODITECT is
  flagship)

  ---
  Step 2: Audit & Archive

  Before renaming 100+ repos, first reduce the number:

  1. Archive stale repos - Anything not touched in 6+ months
  2. Merge duplicates - Consolidate overlapping repos
  3. Delete experiments - One-off tests that aren't needed

  You might reduce from 100+ to 40-50 active repos.

  ---
  Step 3: Apply Naming Convention

  Once consolidated and cleaned, apply the category prefix system:

  coditect-core-*      # Foundation (framework, distribution, 
  infrastructure)
  coditect-cloud-*     # Cloud platform (backend, frontend, api)
  coditect-dev-*       # Developer tools (cli, automation, analytics)
  coditect-market-*    # Marketplace & products
  coditect-docs-*      # Documentation & content
  coditect-gtm-*       # Go-to-market (sales, marketing, competition)
  coditect-labs-*      # Research & experiments

  ---
  Step 4: Phased Execution

  Don't do 100+ renames at once. Phase it:

  | Phase   | Scope                                     | Timeline |
  |---------|-------------------------------------------|----------|
  | Phase 1 | Consolidate orgs, archive stale           | Week 1   |
  | Phase 2 | Rename core repos (framework, cloud, cli) | Week 2   |
  | Phase 3 | Rename tools & features                   | Week 3   |
  | Phase 4 | Rename docs & GTM                         | Week 4   |
  | Phase 5 | Update all references, CI/CD              | Week 5   |

  ---
  Immediate Next Step

  Would you like me to:

  1. Create a full audit - List all repos across all orgs with status
  (active/stale/duplicate)
  2. Start with coditect-rollout-master only - Perfect the 29 submodules
  here first as a pilot
  3. Draft the complete naming convention spec - Document the rules for all
  100+ repos

  Which approach makes sense for where you are right now?

> 1

messages.content:
Good context - that changes the approach significantly. Instead of
  archiving, we should preserve R&D lineage and future roadmap items.

  Created audit: docs/REPOSITORY-AUDIT-2025-11-19.md

  Adjusted Categorization

  For R&D history and future phases, I'd suggest:

  | Category          | Purpose                                     |
  Example Repos                         |
  |-------------------|---------------------------------------------|-------
  --------------------------------|
  | coditect-labs-    | Active experiments, R&D, future phases      |
  graphrag experiments, multi-agent R&D |
  | coditect-history- | R&D that led to CODITECT (preserve lineage) |
  CODITECTv4, early agent frameworks    |

  Or consolidate into one:

  | Category       | Purpose
          |
  |----------------|--------------------------------------------------------
  --------|
  | coditect-labs- | All R&D: past research, active experiments, future
  phase ideas |

  ---
  Key Questions

  To finalize the organization:

  1. R&D Preservation - Should historical R&D repos be:
    - Kept active in coditect-labs-?
    - Archived but tagged for reference?
    - Documented in a "CODITECT Evolution" doc then archived?
  2. Future Phases - Which repos represent future product ideas you want to
  keep accessible?
  3. The "TELLER" repos - Is this a separate product or did it evolve into
  CODITECT?

  Would you like to review the audit document and mark which repos are R&D
  history vs. future phases? I can update the categorization based on your
  input.

> the analysis was really good, obviously any that is under 
coditect-rollout-master and its submodules and submodules of submodles 
thesea are what we are rolling out with, with the analysis we should see if 
any of the others we should merge now. tools add value, etc suggestions for 
a first revision?

messages.content:
First Revision Proposal Created

  Document: docs/ROLLOUT-RESTRUCTURE-PROPOSAL-v1.md

  Summary

  Current: 29 submodules with mixed naming
  Proposed: 32 submodules in 8 clear categories

  Key Recommendations

  Consolidations (reduce complexity):
  - Merge coditect-installer → coditect-ops-distribution
  - Merge coditect-license-server → coditect-ops-license
  - Merge competitive research → coditect-gtm-competition

  Valuable Additions:
  - coditect-dev-pdf - PDF converter tool
  - coditect-docs-training - Training materials
  - coditect-cloud-foundationdb - State storage
  - coditect-market-enterprise - Enterprise agents
  - coditect-labs-agents-research - Active R&D

  Naming Convention:
  coditect-{category}-{name}

  Categories: core, cloud, dev, market, docs, ops, gtm, labs

  Timeline: ~7 Days

  1. Day 1-2: Consolidations
  2. Day 3-4: Renames & transfers
  3. Day 4-5: Add new submodules
  4. Day 5-6: Update all references
  5. Day 6-7: Organize structure

  Questions for You

  1. Subfolders - Organize by category (submodules/core/, submodules/cloud/)
   or keep flat?
  2. Training content - Ready to include in rollout?
  3. FoundationDB - Ready for rollout or still R&D?
  4. What is coditect-projects - How does it differ from rollout-master?

  Want me to refine anything in the proposal before we start executing?

> open the latest revision

messages.content:
What Will Break

  Immediate Breaks (Must Fix)

  | Item            | Impact                                            |
  Fix Effort        |
  |-----------------|---------------------------------------------------|---
  ----------------|
  | .gitmodules     | All submodule URLs invalid                        | 30
   min (scripted) |
  | install.sh URLs | raw.githubusercontent.com/halcasteel/coditect/... | 15
   min            |
  | update.sh URLs  | Same                                              | 5
  min             |
  | CI/CD workflows | Any repo name references                          | 30
   min            |

  Temporary Issues (GitHub Handles)

  | Item            | Impact                     | Duration
      |
  |-----------------|----------------------------|--------------------------
  ----|
  | Old GitHub URLs | Auto-redirect to new names | ~1 year
      |
  | Existing clones | Remote URLs outdated       | Users run git remote 
  set-url |
  | Bookmarks       | Old URLs redirect          | Permanent redirects
      |

  Won't Break

  | Item                  | Why Safe                       |
  |-----------------------|--------------------------------|
  | Internal code imports | Use relative paths             |
  | Local file references | Paths don't include repo names |
  | Package dependencies  | Not published to npm/PyPI      |
  | Database connections  | No repo name dependencies      |

  ---
  Realistic Effort Estimate

  | Task                          | Time   | Can Script?                |
  |-------------------------------|--------|----------------------------|
  | Rename repos on GitHub        | 1 hour | Partially (gh repo rename) |
  | Update .gitmodules            | 30 min | Yes                        |
  | Update install.sh/update.sh   | 20 min | Manual                     |
  | Update READMEs (find/replace) | 1 hour | Yes (sed)                  |
  | Update CLAUDE.md files        | 30 min | Yes                        |
  | Update CI workflows           | 30 min | Manual review              |
  | Move to subfolders            | 1 hour | Scripted                   |
  | Test everything               | 1 hour | Manual                     |

  Total: ~6-8 hours of focused work

  ---
  Risk Mitigation

  1. GitHub redirects protect external links
  2. Do it in one session - don't leave half-renamed
  3. Script the bulk changes - reduce human error
  4. Test install.sh immediately after updating URLs

  ---
  Bottom Line

  Low risk, medium effort. The main pain is the volume of changes, not the
  complexity. Most "breaks" are just URL updates that we control.

  Want me to start executing? I can begin with:
  1. Generate the complete rename script
  2. Start with consolidations (merges)
  3. Or do a dry-run first to show exactly what changes
